subsection.title: Before Class

ol.label: a
ol.li: \ds \lim_{x\to 3} [f(x) + 5g(x)] = 9. Use the sum/difference law to split the limit, then use the constant multiple rule to multiply \ds \lim_{x\to 3} g(x) by 5.
\ds \lim_{x\to 3} [f(x)]^5=-1. Use the power rule to take the power out of the limit, then evaluate.
\ds \lim_{x\to 3} \sqrt{g(x)}=\sqrt{2}. Use the root rule to take the root out of the limit, then evaluate.
\ds \lim_{x\to 3} \dfrac{3f(x)}{g(x)}=-\dfrac{3}{2}. Use the quotient rule to split into two limits, then the constant multiple rule to get \ds \lim_{x\to 3} f(x) by itself.
\ds \lim_{x\to 3} \dfrac{g(x)}{h(x)} does not exist. There is a non-removable factor of 0 in the denominator.
\ds \lim_{x\to 3} \dfrac{f(x)h(x)}{g(x)}=0. Use the quotient rule to split into two limits, then the product rule to split the numerator into two limits as well.

example.solution: Since we can't use the direct substitution property, we split into right- and left-hand limits. \ds \lim_{x\to a^+} |x-a| = \lim_{x\to a^+} (x-a) = a-a = 0 \ds \lim_{x\to a^-} |x-a| = \lim_{x\to a^-} -(x-a) = -a+a = 0 Since the left- and right-hand limits are the same, we conclude that \ds \lim_{x\to a} |x-a|=0

theorem.title: Limit Inequality
theorem.statement: If f(x)\leq g(x) when x is near a (except possibly at a) and the limits of f and g both exist as x approaches a, then \ds\lim_{x\to a} f(x)\leq \lim_{x\to a} g(x)

theorem.title: Squeeze Theorem
theorem.statement: If f(x)\leq g(x)\leq h(x) when x is near a (except possibly at a) and \ds\lim_{x\to a} f(x) = \ds\lim_{x\to a} h(x) = L, then \ds \lim_{x\to a} g(x) = L

example.statement: Use the Squeeze Theorem to show that \ds \lim_{x\to 0} x^2 \sin \lrpar{\dfrac{1}{x}}= 0
example.solution: Since -1\leq \sin\theta \leq 1, it must be true that -1\leq \sin\lrpar{\dfrac{1}{x}}\leq 1. Then, -x^2\leq x^2\sin\lrpar{\dfrac{1}{x}}\leq x^2. Since \ds\lim_{x\to 0} (-x^2) = 0 and \ds \lim_{x\to 0} x^2 = 0, we conclude that \ds \lim_{x\to 0} x^2 \sin \lrpar{\dfrac{1}{x}}= 0 by the Squeeze Theorem.
